item.title: Learn x86-64 assembly by writing a GUI from scratch
item.description: - The article provides a tutorial on how to write an assembly program that opens a GUI window using X11 without external libraries, emphasizing the use of system calls and stack pointers.

item.title: Show HN: I made CSS Pro, a re-imagined Devtools for web design
item.description: - CSS Pro is a browser extension that allows for visual editing of CSS, generating code on-the-fly and allowing changes to any website's design with just a few clicks.

item.title: Zig is hard but worth it
item.description: - Zig programming language is considered challenging but rewarding to master for its unique features that contribute to writing performant software and learning memory management.

item.title: Security.txt file now mandatory for Dutch government websites
item.description: - The security.txt file on a web server contains the contact information for making contact if any vulnerabilities are found on that server.

item.title: Ask HN: Who is hiring? (June 2023)
item.description: - This post is a forum for job seekers in the tech industry to share information about job openings at their companies or to seek out job opportunities.

item.title: Meta announces its Quest 3 VR headset
item.description: - Meta has announced its Quest 3 VR headset, which will be released this fall and cost $499.99 for the 128GB version.

item.title: I went down the rabbit hole of buying GitHub Stars, so you won't have to
item.description: - The article explores the trend of buying GitHub stars as a marketing technique, and the author conducted an experiment of buying stars from different platforms.

item.title: Lost John Coltrane recording, from experimental phase with Eric Dolphy, emerges
item.description: - After being lost for over 60 years, a recording of John Coltrane and Eric Dolphy's experimental performance at the Village Gate in New York has been found and will be released by Impulse!

item.title: Was modern art a CIA psy-op? (2020)
item.description: - Modern art was a weapon of the Cold War, with both the State Department and CIA supporting exhibitions of American art all over the world.

item.title: Industry docs reveal makers of 'forever chemicals' covered up health dangers
item.description: - Makers of the PFAS chemicals, also known as 'forever chemicals,' have covered up the health dangers of these chemicals, according to secret industry documents discovered in a lawsuit filed by attorney Robert Bilott.
